# DEVELOPING A NEW

BUSINESS TYPE RELATIONSHIP:

#### *CHILD-FOCUSED VS. SELF-FOCUSED*

![][image7]

Developing a New Business Type Relationship – *Child-Focused vs. Self-Focused and BeH2OTM Journal*

**MINDFUL MOMENT	Be H2O™ JOURNAL** 

Conditional space in between reading Between Two Worlds

by Elizabeth Marquardt.

*“I am seven years old and climbing the jungle gym outside my school when I overhear two mothers, standing nearby. One says, ‘Kids with divorced parents are kicked back and forth like a football.’ The image grabs me. In this small, rural community, I had never heard anyone talk about divorce, even though my own parents had separated when I was two years old and divorced a year later. The divorce was a silent fact of my life, unnoticed by other kids, mentioned by adults only when they asked me how my father was doing when I came back from visiting him.*

*Kicked back and forth like a football. Even a seven-year-old could sense that this was bad; no one likes to be kicked. But it sounded playful as well. I could see me- the football- flying end over end against a blue sky. It was the kick and the thud on the other end that imparted a vague sense of threat.*

*Sometime later, while visiting my father, I tried out the idea, mentioning lightly that I was kicked back and forth like a football between him and my mother. His face turned a deep purplish red, his libs tightened, he sputtered. He looked the same way whenever he was angry- this time at the person who had said such a thing to me. He sought to regain control and assured me, sternly, that this image did not apply to me. He and my mother loved me, he said. That saying about the football was about kids whose parents didn’t love them.*

*I had to admit, at the time and over the years, that I didn’t feel as if my parents were trying to pass me off to each other. I never felt a rough kick at the airport or at the beginning of the long car ride. On the contrary, my parents were always sad to see me go, and we hugged excitedly when I ran to one of them after a long separation.*

*Still, there was something about that football. I could see it spinning in its arc, flying freely, even beautifully, from the one who launched it to the one who caught it. But it flew with*  
*a freedom that put a catch in my throat. It seemed almost too high, too free; it belonged neither to the place it had left nor the place where it was going. Maybe it belonged in that space in between. And what a conditional space that was.”*

**CONDITIONAL SPACE IN BETWEEN FACILITATOR INSTRUCTION | READING AND INTRODUCING THE CONDITIONAL SPACE CONCEPT**

Begin by reading an excerpt from Elizabeth Marquardt’s Between Two Worlds to the group. This reading offers an important perspective on the unique experience of children navigating life between two separated households. After reading, take a moment to allow participants to reflect on the message.

Introduce the concept by explaining, “Throughout our work in BeH2O™, we will explore ways to help our children adjust and find stability. While we can support them, it’s important to understand that we cannot entirely remove the ‘conditional space’ that exists between their two worlds. As parents, however, you have the ability to develop a heightened awareness of this conditional space and recognize how it may impact your child’s emotions and responses. By understanding this, you can better support your child’s transitions between homes, making their journey between two households smoother and more manageable.”

Encourage parents to consider how this understanding can shape their interactions, allowing them to become more attuned to their child’s unique needs and feelings as they move through these two worlds.

Processing the Video Vignettes – *Supporting Our “Why” and Our Child’s “Why”*

**EXPLORING THE PARENT’S AND CHILD’S “ WHY ”**

Throughout these video vignettes, it is crucial to reflect on not only the decisions made by each parent but also the “why” behind these decisions. Understanding and supporting our own “why”—our values, desires, and goals as

parents—is important, but we must do so without undermining our co-parent’s “why” or the child’s relationship with both parents.

In each situation:

* What is your “why”? Reflect on what drives your decision-making in moments of conflict.

* What is your child’s “why”? How are they navigating the space between two parents, and how can you support their emotional needs?

* How can you make decisions that align with your “why” and your child’s “why” without undermining your co- parent’s role or relationship?

  **HOW CHILDREN UNINTENTIONAL LY PUT THEMSELVES IN THE MIDDLE** 

  ![][image4]	Surviving the Conditional Space in Between

  Children can sometimes feel caught between two worlds, unintentionally placing themselves in the middle of

  co-parenting conflicts. It’s essential to understand how we, as parents, can help them navigate this space without causing further emotional strain.

  Key Point: Our children may not always tell the full story or may share only what they think one parent wants to hear, creating an emotional tug-of-war.

  Discussion Prompts

* How could the father have handled the situation differently to maintain the child’s trust while still respecting the co-parent relationship?

* How could the mother have responded in a way that supported her child’s feelings without undermining the co- parent’s role?

* What is each parent’s “why” in this situation, and how can they make decisions that uphold their values without placing the child in the middle?

* Reflect on the child’s experience—what is the child’s “why” in this situation, and how can both parents support that without compromising their co-parent’s relationship with the child?

![][image3]	Disparaging the Other Parent

Key Point: Children may speak negatively about the co-parent or the co-parent’s family to align with the parent they are with or to make that parent feel better. This can be an unintentional cry for attention or affection but can harm the child’s relationship with both parents.

Discussion Prompts

* Why might the child have disparaged the other parent?

* What emotional needs is the child trying to fulfill in this moment?

* How could each parent handle these situations in a way that supports the child’s emotional well-being without encouraging this behavior?

* What is the parent’s “why” in this scenario? How can the parents avoid undermining each other while supporting the child’s “why” and maintaining a healthy relationship with both parents?

  **PARENTS PUTTING KIDS IN THE MIDDLE** 

![][image3]	“Why is that your business? Why should I tell him/her that?”

Key Point: When one parent fails to communicate important information with their co-parent, the child is often left to act as a messenger. While it may seem easier for the parent to avoid confrontation, it places the child in an emotionally vulnerable position, forced to navigate a “landmine” of conflicting emotions and expectations.

Discussion Prompts

* Why might the mother have chosen not to share important information with the father?

* How did this decision impact the child’s emotional well-being?

* If the situation remained unchanged, how could the father have responded in a way that supported the child without reinforcing the child’s role as a go-between?

* How can parents balance their need for autonomy (their “why”) with the responsibility to communicate in a way that supports their child’s emotional health and respects the co-parent’s role?

![][image3]	Unintended Guilt

Key Point: Sometimes, unresolved desires or unprocessed grief over the end of a relationship can lead parents to unintentionally deprive their child of childhood experiences. This can happen when parents overly focus on their own needs or emotions, without considering the child’s right to enjoy their own childhood.

Discussion Prompts

* Do you think the father intended to rob his child of joyful childhood memories with friends?

* What was the father focused on in this situation?

* How could the father have handled this in a way that prioritized the child’s present experience without undermining his relationship with the child or co-parent?

* How can both parents work together to support their child’s emotional needs (the child’s “why”) while also respecting each other’s “why” in the process?

  Processing the Video – *Impact of Conversations on Our Children*

  Video Discussion Overview: Co-parents will watch a video that highlights the emotional burden children experience when they try to make everyone around them happy. The video shows a little girl who is trying to ensure that her nana and others are happy, a reflection of the emotional labor children often take on in high-conflict co-parenting situations.

  [Video Link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YsvQ7SsEFdQ)

  DISCUSSION POINTS 

1. The Child’s Perspective:

   * Key Point: Children, like the little girl in the video, often try to please everyone. They don’t want anyone to be upset, and they bear the emotional burden of keeping the peace between the adults in their life.

   * Discussion Prompt: How does the little girl in the video seem to feel about the situation? What do you think she wants for her nana and everyone around her?

   * Explore the Child’s “Why”: The little girl’s “why” is simple—she wants everyone to be happy. But when children take on this role, they experience stress and anxiety that can affect their development and well- being.

2. The Impact of Conversations on Children:

   * Key Point: The conversations we have about our co-parent in front of our children, even when we think they aren’t listening, leave a lasting impact. Children absorb more than we realize, and negative comments about the co-parent create confusion and stress for the child.

   * Discussion Prompt: How do you think negative conversations about a co-parent affect the child emotionally? How do children reconcile these mixed messages when they love both parents but hear hurtful things from one about the other?

3. Parentification:

   * Key Point: Parentification occurs when a child is forced to act as the emotional or physical caregiver to a parent or sibling. This role reversal places an enormous burden on the child, who feels responsible for the happiness and emotional well-being of the adults in their life.

   * Discussion Prompt: How might this little girl feel if she believes it’s her job to make sure everyone is happy? What does it do to a child’s sense of security when they feel like they have to manage adult emotions and conflicts?

   * Explore Parentification: Parentification undermines a child’s security, placing them in a role they aren’t emotionally equipped to handle. This can negatively impact their development and well-being.

4. The Impact on Children’s Energy and Development:

   * Key Point: Children have a limited amount of energy, and it should be spent on growing, learning, and developing—not on managing adult conflicts. When children are forced to focus on adult issues, such as mediating between co-parents or pleasing both sides, it distracts from their emotional and cognitive development.

   * Discussion Prompt: What happens to a child’s energy and focus when they are caught in the middle of co- parenting conflicts? How does it impact their ability to grow and develop as they should?

5. Actions Speak Louder Than Words:

   * Key Point: Children learn by observing our actions. We tell our children to be kind, but if we aren’t kind to one another as co-parents, we send a conflicting message. This contradiction undermines their ability to trust us.

   * Discussion Prompt: How can children trust us when we don’t practice what we preach? What are we teaching them if we tell them to be nice, but we can’t be nice to each other?

   **REFLECTING ON THE PARENT’S “ WHY ” AND THE CHILD’S “ WHY ”**

   The Parent’s “Why”: Parents often make decisions based on their own emotional needs or frustrations. But in doing so, they can overlook the emotional cost to their child. By reflecting on their “why,” parents can ensure that their actions align with their desire to support their child’s emotional health, rather than placing an unnecessary burden on them.

   The Child’s “Why”: Children, like the girl in the video, want everyone to be happy, but they aren’t equipped to manage adult emotions. When parents recognize their child’s “why,” they can make choices that respect the child’s emotional boundaries and development, rather than placing the child in the middle of adult conflict.

   **KEY TAKEAWAYS** 

* Children, like the girl in the video, often feel responsible for maintaining peace in their family, which places an enormous burden on them.

* Conversations about the co-parent in front of the child, especially negative ones, create emotional confusion and stress for the child.

* Parentification places children in an adult role, causing them to sacrifice their childhood and development to meet their parents’ emotional needs.

* Our actions teach our children far more than our words. Being kind and respectful to our co-parent is essential to modeling the behaviors we want our children to adopt.

* Reflecting on the “why” behind our actions as parents and understanding the “why” behind our child’s emotions can help us make better decisions that support the child’s emotional health and development.

  ###### Parent-Child Relationship Continuum Post-Separation

  No two relationships are ever identical—this is true for children and parents as well. It is natural for children to have preferences or affinities based on shared experiences or unique dynamics with each parent. However, after a divorce or separation, there is often an expectation that children will suddenly have identical relationships with both parents. This expectation is not reflective of real life. Every relationship is unique, and preferences can change over time.

  **CONTINUUM OF PARENT-CHILD RELATIONSHIPS | AFFINITY, ALLIANCE, ESTRANGEMEN T, AND ALIENATION** 

  Positive Relationship: A child feels equally comfortable and desires to spend time with both parents. They move freely between homes and enjoy relationships with both parents.

  Affinity: Affinity refers to a child’s natural preference for one parent over the other in certain activities, topics, or interests. This is a normal part of any relationship. Just as a child may prefer to do certain activities with one parent, such as fishing or cooking, this affinity can shift over time based on circumstances or shared experiences.

  Key Point: Affinity is natural, not a sign of favoritism or rejection. Children don’t have the same relationship with both parents, and that’s okay. It’s important for parents to recognize that these preferences will ebb and flow, and trying to force a child to have identical relationships with both parents is unrealistic.

  Example 1

  Situation: Dad has always coached his son’s baseball team and shares a love of the sport. The son prefers to go to Royals games with Dad because it’s their special activity together.

  Answer: Affinity

  Alliance: In an alliance, a child outwardly expresses a stronger bond with one parent over the other. This may be due to shared experiences or the amount of time spent with one parent. Alliances often form based on a child’s need for comfort and familiarity in uncertain times, such as during or after a separation.

  Key Point: An alliance does not mean the other parent is unimportant or rejected. It reflects a child’s need for security or comfort during transitions, and with support, children can build stronger relationships with both parents over time.

  Example 2

  Situation: Mom was the primary caregiver during the marriage, caring for the children when they were sick and attending all school events. After the divorce, the children still prefer to turn to Mom for comfort in certain situations.

  Answer: Alliance

  Estrangement: Estrangement occurs when a child resists or refuses contact with a parent due to a realistic and valid reason, such as emotional or physical harm. This form of rejection is based on self-protection and the need to maintain emotional or physical safety.

  Key Point: Estrangement is often the result of a hurtful or harmful experience, and the child’s refusal to see the parent is an attempt to protect themselves from further harm. Understanding the child’s need for safety is critical in addressing this issue.

  Example 3

  Situation: After a difficult incident where Mom was arrested for a DUI with her daughter in the car, the daughter is now resistant to spending time with Mom.

  Answer: Estrangement

  Alienation: Alienation is when a child rejects a parent without any valid reason or justification. This rejection is often accompanied by exaggerated or distorted beliefs about the parent. Alienation can be deliberate, where one parent intentionally manipulates the child’s feelings against the other, but it can also be inadvertent, stemming from a parent’s deep fears and anxieties.

  Key Point: Alienation can sometimes happen unintentionally. A parent’s fear of losing their child or deep emotional pain after the separation can result in behaviors that unintentionally alienate the child from the other parent. When a parent is blinded by their fear, they may not see the child’s need or desire to maintain a relationship with both parents. The fear and anxiety of the parent can subtly transfer to the child, leading to a situation where the child feels they must choose sides or reject one parent to maintain the other’s emotional stability.

  Example 4

  Situation: After Mom discovered Dad had an affair, she shared the details with their daughter, expressing her pain. The daughter, feeling loyalty to Mom, now refuses to see Dad.

  Answer: Alienation

  **EXPLORING THE CHILD’S “ WHY ” AND THE PARENT’S “ WHY ” IN ALIENATION** 

  The Parent’s “Why”: Sometimes a parent is so overcome by fear—fear of losing their child, fear of being replaced—that they inadvertently create an environment where the child feels forced to choose sides. This fear- driven behavior can alienate the child from the other parent, even if the intention wasn’t to cause harm.

  The Child’s “Why”: In cases of alienation, children often believe they are protecting the rejected parent or aligning with the parent who is hurt. The child may feel responsible for the emotional well-being of one parent, and this burden leads them to reject the other parent. Helping the child recognize that they can have a healthy relationship with both parents is key to breaking the cycle of alienation.

  **TAKEAWAYS** 

* Affinity and Alliance: These are natural and should not be seen as negative. Children will always have preferences based on activities, experiences, or emotional needs, and those preferences may shift over time.

* Estrangement: This is a protective mechanism and reflects a need for safety. Estrangement is based on a realistic and valid response to harm.

* Alienation: This is complex and can be either deliberate or unintentional. Fear can play a significant role in creating a situation where a child feels forced to choose sides or reject a parent.

* Parental Awareness: It’s crucial for parents to be aware of their own fears and emotions and how these can impact their child’s relationship with the other parent. Supporting a child’s relationship with both parents is essential to their emotional well-being.

  ###### Parent-Child Relationship Continuum Post-Separation Worksheet Discussion

  Go over the Parent Child Continuum Post-Separation Worksheet together as as a class. Encourage parents to share the answers to each scenario out loud. introduce how this awareness can help parents understand the range of relationships that can emerge between a child and each parent and help parents not to take such as a personal attack but something natural. Working through these concepts together, facilitators can guide parents to see how each type of relationship presents unique needs and considerations in co-parenting.

  **UNDERSTANDING AFFINITY IN PARENT-CHILD RELATIONSHIPS** 

  A special focus on affinity—the natural closeness that arises when a child and parent share common interests or activities—can offer valuable insights. Often, children may miss out on connecting with a parent they share a particular interest with, as they feel pressured to not express themselves or their desire to participate in the activity with a particular parent in order to avoid hurting a parent’s feelings or disrupting a sense of “fairness.”

  For example, a child may avoid asking to participate in an event with particular parent despite the deeply shared common interest, fearing it may seem like favoritism. Yet, expecting children to balance these preferences seamlessly can lead to confusion, guilt, and even resentment over time.

  Facilitators can emphasize that true fairness does not mean identical relationships with each parent; rather, it means respecting and nurturing each unique relationship. Every parent-child relationship naturally differs because each parent brings unique interests, strengths, and qualities to the table, and that diversity is something to celebrate. Just as adult relationships are not identical, it’s healthy and normal for children’s relationships with each parent to reflect individual connections.

  By helping parents explore these insights together, facilitators encourage a mindset that embraces each parent’s unique role in their child’s life, creating space for authentic, positive connections that allow children to thrive.

  Processing the Desperate Housewives Video – *Co-parenting with Empathy, Accountability, and Growth*

  **VIDEO OVERVIEW** 

  In this video clip from Desperate Housewives, Lynette (Mom) initially plots to undermine Tom’s (Dad’s) relationship with their daughter due to her jealousy over the daughter’s fondness for Tom’s new girlfriend. However, by the end of the video, Lynette realizes that her actions are damaging her daughter. She acknowledges her mistakes, shifts her mindset, and takes responsibility for the impact of her actions on her daughter’s emotional well-being. Tom, meanwhile, avoids blaming Lynette for his daughter’s resistance and validates his daughter’s feelings, meeting her where she is emotionally.

  **DISCUSSION POINTS** 

1. Jealousy and Undermining the Co-parent’s Relationship – Lynette’s Initial Actions:

   * Key Point: At the start of the scene, Lynette’s jealousy of Tom’s new relationship leads her to attempt to undermine his bond with their daughter. This is a common reaction for co-parents struggling with the emotions of separation, but it ultimately harms the child. Lynette’s actions reflect her own fears of being replaced, but she fails to see how these actions are hurting her daughter.

   * Discussion Prompt: Why might Lynette have felt tempted to undermine Tom’s relationship with their daughter?

     * How does jealousy or fear of being replaced lead to behaviors that may harm the child’s relationship with the other parent?

     * How might a parent recognize when their own emotions, such as jealousy, are driving their actions, rather than focusing on the child’s well-being?

2. Lynette’s Shift – Realizing the Impact on the Child:

   * Key Point: By the end of the scene, Lynette has an important realization—her actions were not just hurting Tom, but also damaging her daughter. She acknowledges this shift by taking accountability for what she said and refocusing on her daughter’s needs rather than her own emotions. This turning point demonstrates the power of self-awareness in co-parenting.

   * Discussion Prompt: How does Lynette’s realization that she was harming her daughter change the way she approaches the situation?

     * Why is it important for co-parents to recognize when their actions are damaging their child’s relationship with the other parent, even unintentionally?

     * How can parents create space for self-reflection to recognize when their own emotional struggles may be influencing their behavior?

3. Taking Accountability – Lynette’s Growth:

   * Key Point: Lynette’s growth is highlighted by her ability to take responsibility for her actions. She tells her daughter, “I said a lot of things I shouldn’t have. There are no bad guys here, just people trying to figure things out.” By owning her mistakes, she models accountability and shows her daughter that even when emotions run high, it’s possible to repair relationships.

   * Discussion Prompt: What impact does Lynette’s accountability have on her daughter’s emotional well-being?

     * How can taking responsibility for our actions, as Lynette did, create a foundation for healing and repairing relationships?

     * How might this shift in behavior improve the co-parenting dynamic between Lynette and Tom?

4. Meeting the Child Where They Are – Tom’s Response:

   * Key Point: Tom, rather than placing blame on Lynette for their daughter’s resistance, focuses on validating his daughter’s feelings. He meets her where she is emotionally, acknowledging that her feelings are real, even if they stem from Lynette’s influence. Tom’s approach shows empathy, which helps to maintain a connection with his daughter without creating further conflict.

   * Discussion Prompt: Why is it crucial for Tom not to place blame on Lynette in this moment?

     * How does Tom’s ability to meet his daughter where she is, rather than forcing her to change her feelings, demonstrate emotional intelligence in co-parenting?

     * What can we learn from Tom’s approach about the importance of validating our children’s feelings, even when they may be influenced by external factors?

   **WHY I WOULD WANT EITHER OF THESE PARENTS AS A COACHING CLIENT** 

   Lynette’s Growth and Accountability: Initially, Lynette’s jealousy led her to actions that were harmful to her daughter’s relationship with Tom. However, by the end of the scene, she takes a critical step toward self- awareness and growth. She acknowledges that her actions were wrong and focuses on the bigger picture: her daughter’s emotional well-being. This shift demonstrates a willingness to change, which is essential for successful co-parenting. A parent who can reflect on their mistakes and take responsibility is more likely to foster a healthier co-parenting relationship and create a positive environment for their child.

   Tom’s Empathy and Validation: Tom’s approach to his daughter’s resistance is rooted in empathy. Instead of blaming Lynette, he chooses to validate his daughter’s feelings, regardless of how those feelings came about. This empathy strengthens his relationship with his daughter and avoids further conflict with Lynette. Tom’s ability to focus on his daughter’s emotional experience rather than his own need for control or resolution is an example of effective, child-centered co-parenting. Parents who can meet their child where they are emotionally and prioritize their child’s well-being are excellent coaching clients.

   Discussion Prompts for Participants

* Dealing with Jealousy: What can we learn from Lynette’s initial response to her daughter’s fondness for Tom’s new partner?

  * How does jealousy or fear of being replaced sometimes lead to behaviors that damage a child’s relationship with their other parent?

  * How can parents recognize when these emotions are driving their actions and shift their focus back to the child’s well-being?

* The Power of Self-Reflection: How did Lynette’s realization about her impact on her daughter change her behavior?

  * What steps can we take as co-parents to regularly reflect on whether our actions are supporting or undermining our child’s relationship with the other parent?

* Validating Feelings: Why is it important, as Tom demonstrated, to validate your child’s feelings, even if you believe those feelings are influenced by the other parent?

  * How does validating feelings, rather than trying to change them, help build trust with your child?

  Key Takeaways

* Jealousy and Fear: Recognizing and addressing feelings of jealousy or fear of being replaced is critical to preventing behaviors that harm the child’s relationship with both parents.

* Growth and Accountability: Taking accountability, as Lynette eventually does, helps repair relationships and models positive behavior for children.

  – Empathy and Validation: Meeting children where they are emotionally, as Tom does, builds trust and strengthens the parent-child relationship. This approach reduces conflict and keeps the focus on the child’s emotional well-being.

  ###### A New Joint Parenting Relationship

  In co-parenting, the goal is not to become best friends, but rather to co-exist and create a harmonious environment for your child. This is much like managing a successful business partnership: it’s about collaboration, respecting boundaries, and leveraging each person’s unique strengths to achieve a common goal.

  **STEERING THE CO-PARENTING CANOE | A SHIFT IN PERSPECTIVE** 

  Introduce the concept to parents of imagining you and your co-parent are steering a canoe together. Each of you holds an oar, but constantly trying to control how the other person rows will lead to frustration, conflict, and little progress. Instead, focus on your own oar during your parenting time and trust that your co-parent will steer the canoe when it’s their turn. You’ll still need to communicate about obstacles along the way, but dictating how your co-parent rows is not necessary—and it will only create more tension.

  This dynamic is similar to how colleagues collaborate in a business setting. You don’t tell your colleague how to manage their personal life or dictate how they should handle their tasks. Instead, you focus on your own responsibilities and trust that they will do the same.

  Step One | Grieving the Loss of Control

  In order to create a successful co-parenting relationship, parents must first grieve the loss of control over decisions their co-parent makes during their parenting time. Holding onto control only leads to conflict and distracts from the bigger picture—their child’s well-being.

  In business, the Entrepreneurial Operating System (EOS) teaches that leadership requires delegation and trust. You cannot micromanage every aspect of the business, and the same applies to co-parenting. Letting go of control over minor decisions frees up your energy to focus on more important matters.

  **ACTIVITY | GRIEVING THE LOSS OF CONTROL** 

* Complete Part One of the A New Joint Parenting Relationship worksheet. This worksheet lists common day- to-day parenting decisions.

* Group Exercise: Go around the room and ask each participant to name 2-3 items from their list. Write these on the whiteboard.

* Crossing Out the List: After the list is complete, cross out the decisions that are out of each parent’s control during the other’s parenting time. These are the decisions that parents must grieve the loss of control over.

  *DISCUSSION PROMPT*

  Why are we crossing out the majority of these decisions? The truth is, consistency is important for children, but when consistency comes at the cost of daily conflict, the benefits quickly diminish. If you argue over every small decision, it becomes impossible to work together on the bigger, more important issues.

  **ACTIVITY | COST OF CONTROL** 

  Play the last 11 minutes of Tamara D. Afifi’s Ted Talk [“The Impact of Divorce on Children.”](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cKcNyfXbQzQ) In this segment, Afifi explores the emotional effects of conflict between parents and the toll it can take on children. She highlights how children’s stress levels, emotional well-being, and overall development are significantly impacted by the nature of their parents’ interactions post-divorce.

  *KEY CONCEPTS FROM THE TED TALK*

1. The Emotional Cost of Parental Conflict:

   * Afifi illustrates how children experience significant stress when they are caught in the middle of their parents’ conflicts. Even if the parents are consistent with schedules or routines, the ongoing conflict undermines the sense of safety and stability for the child.

   * Children are highly attuned to their parents’ emotional states and can internalize the stress and tension, leading to long-term psychological effects.

2. Consistency vs. Conflict:

   * While consistency in co-parenting is typically seen as beneficial, Afifi points out that when consistency involves constant exposure to conflict or tension, the harm outweighs the benefits.

   * The cost of consistency is too high when rigid adherence to routines leads to increased conflict. In such cases, flexibility and adaptation may serve the child’s emotional needs better.

3. Protecting the Child from Conflict:

   * Afifi emphasizes that reducing exposure to conflict is more critical than maintaining a consistent schedule if that schedule heightens stress for both parents and the child.

   * Children benefit more from a peaceful, emotionally safe environment where parents are not in constant tension, even if this means adapting routines or adjusting expectations to reduce conflict.

   *FACILITATOR-LED DISCUSSION*

   After the video, guide the participants through a discussion on the following points:

1. Understanding the Cost of Conflict:

   * Discuss how ongoing tension between co-parents affects children, even when routines are consistent.

   * Ask participants to reflect on whether their focus on maintaining rigid consistency in their co-parenting routines might sometimes lead to unnecessary conflict, and how this conflict may be impacting their child.

2. The Balance Between Consistency and Flexibility:

   * Encourage participants to consider situations where sticking to a routine or agreement might escalate conflict.

   * Discuss the possibility of introducing more flexibility when necessary to prioritize emotional peace over rigid schedules.

3. Prioritizing Emotional Safety:

   * Emphasize that the ultimate goal in co-parenting is not just maintaining consistent logistics but ensuring the child feels safe and free from parental tension.

     – Ask participants to think about how they can create emotionally safe spaces for their children, even if that means being more adaptable with certain co-parenting arrangements.

     *KEY POINTS TO EMPHASIZE*

1. Consistency is Important, but Not at Any Cost: While children benefit from routines and predictability, this should not come at the expense of their emotional safety. If strict consistency leads to high conflict, the cost is too high.

2. Adaptation Over Rigidness: Co-parenting requires flexibility, especially when conflict arises. Being willing to adapt schedules or arrangements to reduce tension can provide a more peaceful environment for the child.

3. Minimize Exposure to Conflict: Children are deeply affected by conflict between their parents. Co-parents should prioritize reducing conflict over adhering strictly to co-parenting plans or routines.

   *REFLECTION EXERCISE*

   Go through your list of day-to-day parenting decisions and cross out those decisions that your co-parent makes during their parenting time. Grieving the loss of control over these smaller decisions will allow you to free up mental and emotional space for reaching agreements on the larger, more impactful issues.

   Step Two | Focusing on Strengths, Not Rights

   In business and in co-parenting, focusing on strengths is far more effective than focusing on rights. As stressed by Entrepreneurial Operating System (EOS), a business thrives when the right people are in the right seats, allowing each person’s strengths to drive success. Similarly, children flourish when parents focus on their strengths rather than weaknesses, positioning them to grow with confidence and purpose. The key is to focus on the strengths that each parent brings to the table, not on a rigid sense of rights or entitlement.

   *LET’S GET THE ISSUE OF RIGHTS OUT OF THE WAY*

   Parents have the “right” to make decisions for their child. But just because parents have the right to do something, doesn’t mean they should always be the one to do it. Why? Because focusing on strengths—not rights—creates the best outcomes for children.

   Consider this example: I have the right to teach my child to play baseball, but I know my co-parent is better equipped to do so. Similarly, my co-parent has the right to take our daughter to get her hair cut, but I may be better suited to handle that task. It’s about knowing who is more proficient in certain areas and allowing that person to take the lead.

   Another example: A dad once approached me upset because his co-parent took their daughter to get her hair cut. He asked, “Should I be mad? I have the right to take her.” I responded, “Do you like her haircut?” He said yes. Then I asked, “Did you want to take her?” He said no. So, I asked, “What’s the issue?” The point is, rights are often used as a reason for conflict, when in reality, focusing on strengths better serves the children.

   *BUSINESS ANALOGY: DELEGATING BASED ON STRENGTHS*

   In business, you delegate tasks based on each person’s skill set, not their “right” to do the job. You wouldn’t assign marketing responsibilities to your accountant. Similarly, in co-parenting, if one parent has a strength in a particular area, why wouldn’t we want that parent to take the lead in that space? Why would we want anything less for our child?

   **ACTIVITY | FOCUSING ON STRENGTHS, NOT RIGHTS** 

* Complete Part Two of the A New Joint Parenting Relationship worksheet.

* Group Discussion: How could focusing on strengths lead to parenting plans that better meet the needs of your child, rather than parenting plans that focus on parental rights?

* Reflection: Consider what each of you brings to the table as a parent. What strengths do you have that benefit your child, and how can you allow your co-parent to take the lead in areas where they excel?

  **DISCUSSION PROMPT**

  Far too often, co-parents argue based on their “rights,” but this often misses the point. Who is better equipped to handle certain aspects of parenting? Who did what during the marriage, and why wouldn’t that continue? If one parent has a strength in a certain area, why not let them take the lead for the sake of the child?

  **KEY TAKEAWAYS** 

* Grieving the Loss of Control: Accepting that you can’t control every decision your co-parent makes during their time is essential to reducing conflict and focusing on the bigger issues that matter for your child.

* Focusing on Strengths, Not Rights: Parenting should be about using each parent’s strengths to best support the child. Just as in business, delegating based on skill set produces better outcomes. Shifting from a mindset of control and entitlement to a mindset of collaboration will foster healthier co-parenting relationships and a better environment for your child.

  **HOMEWORK** 

  Review homework assignment: explore your child’s conditional space.

# DEVELOPING EMPATHY FOR YOUR CHILD’S POSITION AND UNDERSTANDING YOUR

CO-PARENTING RELATIONSHIP

![][image7]

###### Developing Empathy for Your Child’s Position and Understanding Your Co-parenting Relationship

Overview: This session is designed to enhance co-parents’ understanding and empathy toward their child’s emotional experience in navigating their relationships. Through targeted empathy exercises and creative expression, parents will be encouraged to view their dynamics from their child’s perspective. The session culminates in identifying a small, intentional action that both parents agree to undertake, aimed at improving their child’s sense of security and comfort.

Objective/Why: The goal is for co-parents to commit to a unified, small action that subtly enhances their child’s emotional comfort. This session emphasizes the importance of incremental change and how small, consistent actions can lead to significant transformation over time.

**MINDFUL MOMENT** 

![][image10] **Be H2O™ JOURNAL** 

**REVIEW OF REFLECTIVE LISTENING SKILLS SESSION DETAILS**

1. Bridge Exercise Overview: Purpose of the Exercise The bridge exercise included in the participant manual serves as a preparatory activity to help co-parents visualize and empathize with their child’s experiences navigating the transition between two homes. This exercise is foundational in setting the context for deeper empathy and understanding during the sessions.

   Facilitators should reference the bridge exercise briefly at the beginning of the session to connect the dots between the homework and the day’s activities. This reference is intended to remind parents of the perspectives

   they considered while completing the exercise and to use those insights as a springboard for the day’s discussions.

   Suggested Language for Facilitators: “Let’s begin today by acknowledging the bridge exercise you completed as part of your homework. This exercise was designed to help you start thinking about the emotional and physical transition your child experiences between your two homes. While we won’t dive into specific details from your submissions, keep your insights in mind as they are crucial for today’s activities. Today, we build on that foundation, exploring deeper into your child’s emotional landscape and how we, as co-parents, can make this journey more comfortable for them.”

2. Review of BeH2O™ Commitment: Begin by revisiting the BeH2O™ commitment signed in the first class. Encourage each parent to identify which aspect they find most challenging for themselves not their co- parent and discuss how clarity in their intentions can help address these challenges. Highlight that though the process is tough, focused and clear goals lead to easier execution and gradual improvement.

3. Empathy Exercise: Bear Cards: Distribute bear cards to each parent, asking them to choose three to five cards they think their child might use to describe their relationship (meaning the parents relationship with each other NOT the parents relationship with the child). Have each parent explain their selections, as the facilitator reflects back what you understand each parent to say, facilitating a reflection on how their relationship might be perceived from their child’s point of view.

4. Artistic Expression: Drawing the Child’s Emotional Landscape: Provide materials for parents to draw what they believe their child feels being emotionally situated between them. Ask parents to imagine what it feels like for their child to have two parents who they love viewing one another in that way. Children live in that conditional space—always carrying the presence of both parents, even when they are physically with only one. Remind parents that this experience goes beyond transitions; when a child is in one home, thoughts of the other parent don’t simply disappear. Ask parents to draw how it feels for their child to live in that

   conditional space. Have each parent share and explain their picture. Use examples from previous sessions, like a child feeling like a tiny figure between two towering figures, or caught in a tornado of emotions, to help parents visualize and articulate these feelings.

5. Empathy Exercise: Feeling Cards: Following the artistic expression, introduce feeling cards. Have parents select three to five cards that they believe represent their child’s emotional response to the dynamics they’ve just illustrated. This step deepens the parents’ insight into the impact of their relationship on their child. After each parent selects the feeling cards that describe how they believe their child feels living in that conditional space, invite one parent to go through their set of cards individually. As they share, reflect back the feelings expressed, ask clarifying questions, and encourage them to explore each feeling in depth. When the first parent has finished, give the second parent the same opportunity to share their set of feeling cards, providing reflective and clarifying feedback. Emphasize feelings as appropriate to reinforce understanding and empathy.

6. Identifying Emotional Needs: Using need cards, ask parents to identify three to five cards they believe their child needs to resolve their negative feelings related to living in the conditional space between their two worlds to feel more secure and supported. Invite one parent to go through their set of cards individually. As they share, reflect back the needs expressed, ask clarifying questions, and encourage them to explore each need in depth, asking “if you and your co-parent were filling this need for your child, what would it look like?” When the first parent has finished, give the second parent the same opportunity to share their set of needs cards, providing reflective and clarifying feedback. Continue to repeat and emphasize needs as appropriate to reinforce understanding. This discussion should build on the feelings identified in the previous exercise, aiming to address these emotions through tangible actions.

7. Collaborative Decision on One Small Thing: Guide parents to collaboratively decide on one small, practical action they can both undertake to address the identified needs. This action should be subtle yet impactful, noticeable to the child without being explicitly announced.

   Facilitate a brainstorming session, suggesting examples like:

   * Unified Greeting: Both parents could agree to always smile and give a thumbs-up to each other at exchanges, demonstrating cordiality.

   * Consistent Comfort Item: Agreeing on a comfort item like a small toy or blanket that moves with the child between homes to provide continuity and security.

8. Conclusion and Commitment: Conclude the session by having each parent commit to the agreed-upon action. Emphasize the importance of consistency and the powerful, positive impact of small changes observed over time.

   Facilitator Notes

   * Encourage a cooperative and non-judgmental atmosphere where parents feel safe to express their thoughts and emotions.

   * Use active listening and empathetic reflections to validate each parent’s feelings and foster a collaborative spirit.

   * Support parents in focusing on solutions that are not only feasible but also directly beneficial to their child, reinforcing the session’s goal of making small, meaningful changes.

   This session aims to bridge the gap between understanding a child’s emotional world and taking practical steps to enhance their well-being, leveraging both parents’ commitment to a shared, positive action.

# REDUCING EMOTIONAL REACTIVITY AND SETTING NEW BOUNDARIES:

#### *THE IMPACT OF OUR EMOTIONS ON OUR RELATIONSHIP WITH OUR CO-PARENT AND OUR CHILDREN*

![][image7]

Reducing Emotional Reactivity and Setting New Boundaries: *The Impact of Our Emotions on Our Relationship with Our Co-parent and Our Children*

**MINDFUL MOMENT** 

![][image11] **Be H2O™ JOURNAL PSYCHOEDUCATION**   
![][image3]	Mindful Schools: “Just Breathe” by Julie Bayer Salzman & Josh Salzman –  
[YouTube video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RVA2N6tX2cg)

Facilitator’s Note: Start the class by showing the Mindful Schools: Just Breathe video.

Discussion Prompt: After the video, ask the class: “Why do you think I played this video?”

Facilitator’s Talking Points

* Children show us how their minds work and explain how they calm down when feeling angry.

* We teach these skills to our children, but as adults, we often struggle to make the necessary mindset shifts to use these skills ourselves.

* This can lead us to undermine what we are trying to teach our kids because we fail to implement these calming techniques.

  Transition to Fight, Flight, Freeze, and Fawn Responses

  Use the video discussion as a segue into talking about the fight, flight, freeze, and fawn responses. Explain that as adults, we experience triggers that send us into survival mode, and our reactions often prevent us from accessing our rational minds.

  **FIGH T, FLIGH T, FREEZE, OR FAWN RESPONSE** 

  Facilitator’s Explanation

* When triggered, your sympathetic nervous system kicks into gear, activating your fight, flight, freeze, or fawn response. This system was designed to help us survive.

* In the past, our ancestors needed these responses to escape real dangers, like a saber-tooth tiger. Today, we experience the same response, but to non-life-threatening situations.

* Physically, when triggered, we might experience:

  * Rapid, shallow breathing.

  * A racing heart.

  * Flushed or pale skin.

    *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

    Complete Part One A of the Rewire and Respond: Exploring Your Brain’s Patterns and Potential Worksheet.

    Class Discussion

* Ask parents to share what they feel physically when they are triggered into fight, flight, freeze, or fawn.

* As you go around the room, ask each parent individually what happens in their body before they enter this state.

  **RECOGNIZING THE MOMENT BEFORE** 

  Facilitator’s Response to Parent Answers

  If a parent says they feel it’s too late to stop the response: Explain that *next time this occurs, pay attention to what happens just before it feels ‘too late.’* This moment is the key. Use it as a cue to step into your rational mind before fully entering fight, flight, freeze, or fawn.

  If a parent says they don’t know: Compliment their transparency and self-awareness. *Not knowing is the first step to finding the answer.* Suggest they try a body scan the next time they feel triggered, becoming more aware of the physical sensations that signal the response.

  **QUIETING THE MIND AND BODY**

  Facilitator’s Reflection

  We must go into a place of inner quiet because only there can we truly address the issues that matter and transform discord into understanding.

  *What is happening in your body can alert you to reactive habits that are not serving you. This awareness can give you space to recalibrate your response.*

  **THE SCIENCE OF THE BRAIN** 

  After discussing fight, flight, freeze, and fawn, we move into a deeper understanding of brain science to help parents grasp why these responses happen and how they can gain more control over their reactions.

1. Anatomy of the Brain and How It Works

   *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

   To illustrate how the brain works, we use a variation of Dr. Daniel Siegel’s hand model. Imagine the hand is open with its fingers “on fire,” and a watering hose is being held by the hand to calm these emotions. A lizard near the hand represents the reactive, primitive part of the brain—the “lizard brain.”

   *FACILITATOR’S TALKING POINTS*

* The lizard brain (the most primitive part of our brain) is activated during fight, flight, freeze, or fawn responses. This automatic and protective mechanism is triggered in situations of perceived danger or conflict but is not always helpful in modern conflict resolution.

* The amygdala plays a key role in processing negative events. When negative or threatening situations occur—like feeling blamed—the amygdala interprets everything as a threat and assumes the other person’s actions are intentional. This triggers the fight, flight, freeze, or fawn response, making it difficult to engage in rational thinking or problem-solving.

* In contrast, positive events are processed by the prefrontal cortex, which allows for a more measured and thoughtful response. The prefrontal cortex assumes actions were not done on purpose and allows for greater empathy and creative thinking.

* Blame and the brain: As Michael Timms points out, our brains interpret blame as a physical attack. When someone feels blamed, it activates the amygdala, triggering the fight, flight, or freeze response. This state inhibits the person’s ability to think rationally and solve problems, often leading to defensive or unproductive behaviors. For example, in co-parenting, when one parent blames the other for a child’s behavior, the blamed parent may become defensive, escalating the conflict rather than focusing on solutions.

* Safety and constructive behavior: When individuals feel safe, they are more likely to engage their prefrontal cortex, which enables them to respond to conflicts more rationally and empathetically. As a facilitator, your role is to help co-parents create an environment where they can engage with each other without triggering the amygdala-driven blame response, thus encouraging positive communication.

  *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

  Complete Part One B of the Rewire and Respond: Exploring Your Brain’s Patterns and Potential Worksheet.

  Discuss the parents’ experiences after reviewing the worksheet, with a focus on how negative events, blame, or conflict may have triggered their amygdala, and how they can work on shifting their response to engage their prefrontal cortex for more positive outcomes.

2. Mirror Neurons

   *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

   Mirror neurons are sensory-motor cells in the brain that fire both when an individual performs an action and when they observe another person performing the same action. This means that emotions and behaviors can be contagious.

   ## HAND MODEL OF THE BRAIN

   The Prefrontal Cortex:

   The evolved/rational brain, which has the capacity for language and the ability to put out fires.

“Set the roof on fire”

The Amygdala:

Fight, flight, or freeze big emotions, early reptilian brain.

![][image12]	**VIDEO ACTIVITY**

Play the Mirror Neurons video [YouTube link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5Th0aOoX4EM).

After the video, lead the class through the activity featured in the video.

*FACILITATOR’S TALKING POINTS*

* Mirror neurons explain why our kids pick up on our emotional states. For example, when we feel anxious about sending them to the other parent’s house, they absorb that anxiety and become anxious themselves.

* Likewise, in co-parenting conflict, if we are unaware of how our co-parent’s mirror neurons might be influencing their reactions, we lose the opportunity to shift our own behavior, which could de-escalate a potential conflict.

  *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

  Complete Part Two of the Rewire and Respond: Exploring Your Brain’s Patterns and Potential Worksheet. Encourage the class to reflect on how their emotions may impact their child and co-parent’s reactions.

  ## MIRROR NEURONS

3. Neuroplasticity

   *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

   Neuroplasticity refers to the brain’s ability to reorganize and form new neural connections in response to learning, experience, or recovery from injury.

   Dr. Amen coined the term Automatic Negative Thoughts (ANTs) to describe the habitual negative thoughts that often occur in co-parenting dynamics.

   ![][image5]	**VIDEO ACTIVITY**

   Play the Neuroplasticity video [YouTube link](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1EQ3kAPzVVI).

   *FACILITATOR’S TALKING POINTS*

* Neurons that fire together, wire together—this means that the more often you respond negatively to your co-parent, the more likely you are to continue doing so in the future.

* Conversely, the more often you respond positively or even neutrally to your co-parent, the more likely you will continue this pattern.

* The brain strengthens the behaviors we practice, whether positive or negative. This is why it’s important to be mindful of how we react in co-parenting situations to break negative cycles and form new, healthier patterns.

* Encourage parents to continue tracking their emotional responses, practice mindfulness, and paying attention to physical sensations and mental patters as they occur. Emphasize that just as children can learn to calm themselves, adjust have the power to retrain their own brains through consistent practice.

  *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

  Strengthening Behaviors

  Ask parents to consider how the brain reinforces behaviors—whether positive or negative—through repeated practice. Encourage them to reflect on the following questions:

  What negative cycles or habits in your co- parenting relationship might be unintentionally reinforced? Are there specific patterns you would like to work on breaking?

  What positive behaviors could you intentionally practice to create a healthier dynamic in your co-parenting relationship? How might focusing on these behaviors shift the overall tone and strengthen your co-parenting partnership?

  Encourage parents to identify one small, positive behavior they can start practicing regularly to create lasting, constructive change in their co- parenting relationship.

  ## NEUROPLASTICITY

Neuroplasticity explains how the nervous system learns our postures and movement patterns, as well as our memories and sensitivity to pain.

Neural pathways are like water flowing alongside a mountain.  
When the water first begins flowing, it runs

over the mountain and there is  
no path.

The more the water flows, it begins to etch a path alongside the mountain.

## UNDERSTANDING PERSPECTIVES

**VIDEO ON PERSPECTIVES** 

![][image5]	Facilitator’s Note: Start this section by playing the [Perspectives video.](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bzmWqZS1QSU)

Discussion Prompt: As the video concludes with the question, “Get it?”, follow up by asking the participants, “Do you get it?”

Facilitator’s Talking Points

* We all have a lot going on in our lives, and our perceptions guide the way we act and respond to others.

* How we react to the world shapes the feedback we receive from others. The way your co-parent responds to you may be based on their perceptions of your behavior, and vice versa.

  **HOW WE VIEW A SITUATION WILL HELP US DEEM WHETHER OR NOT A SITUATION IS TRU LY DANGEROUS** 

  Facilitator’s Explanation

  Far too frequently, co-parents say, *“I know what he/she is up to,”* or *“I know him/her better than anyone else.”* But think about it—are you the same person you were when you were together? Chances are, you’re not, and neither is your co-parent.

  You don’t fully know what’s going on in their life now. It’s easy to make assumptions, but those assumptions can create unnecessary tension or conflict.

  **THE STORY OF BOB | SHIFTING PERSPECTIVES** 

  Use the following story to help participants reflect on how their view of a situation can change as they learn more information. Pause after each statement and ask participants to reflect on their thoughts about Bob:

1. Story Introduction: Bob and his wife were going to have their first child.

   Ask: What do you think about Bob?

2. New Information: You find out Bob’s wife is at the hospital giving birth to their first child, and Bob is not there.

   Ask: What do you think about Bob now?

3. Further Information: You learn that Bob got into a wreck on the way to the hospital, which is why he isn’t there.  
   Ask: Does your view of Bob change?

4. Deeper Context: Bob wrecked his car because he took too many hydrocodone on the way to the hospital.

   Ask: What do you think about Bob now?

5. Additional Explanation: Bob suffers from severe migraine headaches and took the medication because he didn’t think he could make it to the hospital otherwise.  
   Ask: How does this information influence your view of Bob?

6. New Fact: You find out Bob recently drove three hours to visit a friend without taking any hydrocodone.

   Ask: What do you think about Bob now?

7. Final Context: Bob went to visit his friend because his friend was at an all-time low, and Bob went to offer him emotional support.

   Ask: How do you feel about Bob now?

   **OPEN DISCUSSION** 

   Facilitator’s Discussion Prompt

* With each new fact about Bob, did your perspective of him change?

* The reality is that we must take the opportunity to understand that there is more going on in our co-parent’s life than we are aware of, and we must have compassion for where they’re coming from—even if we don’t always agree.

*REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

Challenging Perspectives

Invite parents to take a moment to reflect on their assumptions and perspectives regarding their co-parent. Ask them to consider the following:

Can you recall a situation where you assumed you knew what your co-parent was thinking or why they acted a certain way?

How might these assumptions have influenced your response to them? Did it affect the tone, words, or approach you used?

How could challenging or reframing these assumptions create a more open and constructive response in future interactions?

Encourage parents to identify one assumption they could set aside or question to promote a more positive, cooperative dynamic with their co-parent.

**CONFIRMATION BIAS** 

*FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

The root of many issues in high-conflict custody cases stems from confirmation bias. This bias causes parents to gather only the information that supports their existing narrative, rather than seeking a balanced  
understanding of the situation. In co-parenting, this can severely impact relationships, decisions, and ultimately, the well-being of the child.

**VIDEO ACTIVITY**

![][image5]	Play the Bellarmine Studios: [Confirmation Bias video.](https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=HTFdMwCXpMw)

Understanding Confirmation Bias

*FACILITATOR’S TALKING POINTS*

Confirmation bias is the tendency to pay attention only to information that upholds our beliefs while ignoring or dismissing anything that challenges them.

*EXAMPLES OF CONFIRMATION BIAS*

* Only seeking information that supports your beliefs.

  * Discrediting information that challenges your beliefs.

  * Avoiding information that doesn’t fit your existing narrative.

  * Interpreting information in a way that reinforces your viewpoint.

  * Only remembering details that confirm your beliefs.

  * Jumping to conclusions based on your truth rather than the objective reality.

  Why It’s Important to Recognize Confirmation Bias

  Confirmation bias can:

  * Prevent us from looking at situations objectively and lead to uninformed decisions.

  * Result in assumptions, which can provoke reactive decisions that negatively impact our children and co- parenting relationships.

  * Lead to projecting our emotions onto our children, further complicating the co-parenting dynamic.

  *EXAMPLE | A CHILD’S STORY AND CONFIRMATION BIAS AT WORK*

  Facilitator’s Story: Imagine a little girl who just came back from Dad’s house, excited to tell Mom about all the fun things she did. However, Mom is struggling financially and wishes she could provide the same experiences. She fears that Dad might be stealing her daughter’s affection because he can give her more. Mom doesn’t say anything derogatory about Dad, but her internal struggles prevent her from matching her daughter’s excitement. Instead, she responds with a casual, unenthusiastic, “That’s nice.”

  The next time the little girl returns to Mom, she’s visibly upset and says Dad was mean, yelled at her, and ignored her all weekend. This time, Mom empathizes, giving her daughter lots of love and attention, and remembers how difficult her own relationship with Dad was.

  *FACILITATOR’S QUESTION TO THE CLASS*

  Is this little girl more likely to tell her mom positive or negative things about Dad next time?

  Class typically answers: Negative.

  *FACILITATOR’S RESPONSE*

  Exactly. Confirmation bias is at work. Now, Mom is only hearing negative things about Dad. This creates a loop where Mom feels obligated to protect her daughter. After all, the child has nothing good to say about Dad, and if Mom doesn’t step in, she might feel like she’s failing as a parent. Mom files a motion to restrict Dad’s time in court, and soon she’s accused of alienating her daughter from Dad. The reality is that Mom wasn’t doing this intentionally—she was unaware of the bias shaping her reactions.

  **INTRODUCING FUNDAMENTAL ATTRIBUTION BIAS AND SELF-SERVING BIAS** 

  *FACILITATOR’S TALKING POINTS*

  In addition to confirmation bias, two other cognitive biases often complicate co-parenting dynamics:

  fundamental attribution bias and self-serving bias.

  Fundamental Attribution Bias

  This bias occurs when we assume that other people’s actions are due to their personality or character, rather than external factors that might be influencing their behavior.

  * Example in Co-Parenting: A parent might assume that the other parent missed a scheduled pickup because they are irresponsible or don’t care, rather than considering external factors like traffic or a work emergency. This bias makes it harder to see the full picture and understand the constraints the other parent may be facing.

  * Facilitator Question: How might this bias lead to misunderstandings and unnecessary conflict in co- parenting?

    Self-Serving Bias

    This bias occurs when we attribute our own failures to external factors while attributing others’ failures to internal flaws.

    * Example in Co-Parenting: A parent may excuse their own tardiness for pickup by blaming traffic or a busy schedule, but when the co-parent is late, they are labeled as disorganized or lazy. This creates an unfair double standard in the co-parenting relationship and can lead to resentment.

    * Facilitator Question: How could recognizing this bias help reduce tension and improve communication between co-parents?

    How These Biases Affect Co-parenting Relationships

    Fundamental Attribution Bias leads us to blame our co-parent’s character for problems, while self-serving bias allows us to excuse our own behavior. Both biases reinforce negative views of the co-parent and prevent us from seeing the full picture.

    In high-conflict co-parenting situations, these biases can escalate misunderstandings, making it difficult to resolve issues or collaborate effectively.

    *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

    Recognizing Bias in Co-parenting Conflicts

    Ask parents to think back to a recent conflict with their co-parent and consider how certain biases might have shaped their response. Use the following questions to guide their reflection:

    Can you identify moments where confirmation bias (seeking evidence to support your existing beliefs), fundamental attribution bias (assuming your co-parent’s actions reflect their character rather than circumstances), or self-serving bias (attributing positive outcomes to yourself and negative ones to external factors) may have influenced your reaction?

    How might recognizing these biases help you approach future conflicts with greater openness and understanding?

    What specific changes could you make in how you interpret or respond to your co-parent’s actions by challenging these biases?

    Encourage parents to choose one bias they can work on recognizing and re-framing to promote healthier, more constructive interactions with their co-parent.

  **COGNITIVE BEHAVIORAL THERAPY (CBT ), GROWTH MINDSET, AND PARADIGM SHIFTS** 

  The ABC Technique | Understanding Cognitive Re-frames

  *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

  The ABC technique helps us understand how our beliefs about an event shape our reactions:

  A: The Activating event—the trigger or situation you cannot control. This often involves something your co-parent does that pushes you into fight, flight, freeze, or fawn.

  B: Your Beliefs about the event—how you interpret what’s happening.

  C: The Consequences—how you feel or act based on those beliefs.

  *DISCUSSION EXAMPLE*

  Imagine you’re driving and the car in front of you suddenly slams on its brakes. What do you do? You slam on your brakes. Do you take

  a moment to reflect, *“Should I brake or not? Let me think about it?”* No, you react immediately. This is because your belief—“I need to stop or I’ll crash”—is automatic, and you jump straight to the consequence (C).

  The key point: The real work has to be done outside of the triggering event (A) because we often don’t have the time to consciously reflect in the moment. This is where mindset shifts come in.

  Applying the ABC Model: Shifting Automatic Negative Beliefs

  *FACILITATOR’S EXAMPLE*

  Let’s say you’re sitting down to dinner with your child, and the phone rings—it’s your co-parent. What’s your automatic negative belief?

  *CLASS DISCUSSION*

  Participants typically share: “He/she is always interrupting. They must know we’re eating dinner—how rude\!”

  *FACILITATOR’S FOLLOW-UP QUESTIONS*

  * Are you as present with your child after the phone rings?

  Answer: No.

  * Are you as attuned and connected as you were before?

  Answer: No.

  Shifting Your Belief

  Now, let’s try re-framing the automatic belief into something more neutral or positive:

  *NEW BELIEF EXAMPLES*

  * “Maybe they don’t know we’re eating dinner.”

  * “Maybe they just want to talk to our child. I miss them when they’re not with me, so maybe they do too.”

  * “Maybe they have something exciting to share.”

    *FACILITATOR’S KEY POINT*

    * If it’s difficult to re-frame into a positive belief, you can shift your mindset to: “This is an opportunity for me to practice attunement.”

    * I’m not asking you to interrupt your dinner by answering the phone, but instead, don’t let the call spoil your connection. Shift your mindset to align with your co-parenting goal—fostering a healthy relationship between the child and both parents.

  ![][image3]	Parent Triggers

    *KEY POINT*

    Our beliefs surrounding our co-parent’s actions frames our children’s experience.

    *DISCUSSION POINTS*

    How might the mother’s negative thought have impacted the child’s relationship with her? The child’s relationship with the father? How might it have impacted the remainder of Mother’s Day? The child’s time with their father?

    Similarly, in shifting her thought to a more neutral or positive thought, how might such impact her relationship with her child? The child’s relationship with the father? The remainder of her day? The child’s time with the father?

  ![][image3]	Child Triggers

    *KEY POINT*

    Becoming defensive when our child compares us to our co-parent detracts from our ability to focus on the key lessons we are trying to teach our children.

    *DISCUSSION POINTS*

    How might the father’s negative thought have impacted his ability to focus on ensuring the child brushes his teeth? How might it have negatively impacted the child’s relationship with the mother? What was the impact on the child when the father shifted his belief?

    *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

    Invite parents to reflect on a recent challenging interaction with their co-parent by using the following steps:

    Activating Event: What was the specific situation or event that triggered a reaction in you?

    Beliefs: What were your immediate thoughts or beliefs about this event? Identify any automatic negative beliefs that may have come up.

    Consequences: What feelings or actions followed as a result of those beliefs?

    Re-framing Beliefs: Now, think of a more neutral or positive belief that could replace the automatic negative belief. For example:“Maybe they didn’t realize we were busy.”

    “Maybe they wanted an extra moment to connect with our child.”

    How might a shift in your beliefs have changed your feelings, actions, or response in this situation?

    Encourage parents to explore how re-framing their beliefs could lead to a calmer, more constructive response in future interactions.

  **MOVING BEYOND CBT | MINDSET DRIVES BEHAVIOR, AND BEHAVIOR DRIVES RESU LT S** 

  *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

  In most parenting classes, the focus is on changing behaviors—what we do and how we respond to our co-parent. But here’s the key: behavior follows mindset. If we don’t shift our mindset, we can’t consistently perform the behaviors we know are right. We remain stuck in our reactive state—fight, flight, freeze, or fawn—unable to access the calm, rational part of our brain.

  Carol Dweck’s Growth Mindset theory emphasizes that the way we perceive challenges determines our ability to grow. If we view co-parenting difficulties as opportunities to improve ourselves and our relationship with our child, we are more likely to adapt and thrive. Conversely, if we view them as insurmountable, we remain stuck in negative patterns.

  Bob Proctor’s concept of Paradigm Shifts expands on this idea. Our paradigms are deeply ingrained beliefs that govern our thoughts and actions. Often, without realizing it, we operate from old paradigms that limit us. Shifting these paradigms involves a fundamental change in how we think, allowing us to break free from reactive patterns and make real progress.

  This is why it’s crucial to understand that mindset drives behavior, and behavior drives results. The mindset work has to be done outside of those reactive moments. This is a paradigm shift, a fundamental change in how we view co- parenting, our child, and ourselves.

  *FACILITATOR’S TALKING POINTS*

  * If you’re in a reactive state, you can’t apply the strategies or behaviors needed for healthy co-parenting.

  * Shifting your mindset is not something you do in the heat of the moment—it’s done through reflection, self- awareness, and preparation outside of conflict.

  * By shifting our mindset, we invite new behaviors that lead to better results, both for our relationship with our co- parent and for the well-being of our child.

  **PARADIGM SHIFTS | A NEW WAY TO APPROACH CO-PARENTING** 

  *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

  When we struggle to change our belief about our co-parent or the situation, a mindset shift becomes essential. Sometimes, trying to convince ourselves that our co-parent has good intentions feels unrealistic, especially in high-conflict situations. In these cases, forcing yourself to trust your co-parent may not be possible and won’t result in productive behavior changes.

  For example: “This is an opportunity to take a swift pivot, rather than trying to convince myself my co-parent has good intentions.”

  You may not be able to control or trust your co-parent’s intentions, but you can control how you react. This is where a paradigm shift comes into play.

  A paradigm shift allows you to re-frame the situation in a way that helps you navigate

  the co-parenting dynamic more effectively—without needing to change your co-parent or even trust their intentions.

  Examples of Paradigm Shifts

1. “Our children will be more well-rounded because of our differences.”

   Instead of seeing differences in parenting styles as a source of conflict, shift the mindset to view those differences as an opportunity to teach your children resilience and adaptability. By modeling how to respectfully navigate differences, you are equipping your children with the tools they need for life.

2. “This is an opportunity to model for our children how to respectfully resolve conflict.”

   Rather than focusing on winning an argument or proving a point, shift your mindset to see each disagreement as a chance to show your child how conflicts can be handled with respect and maturity, setting a powerful example.

3. “This is an opportunity for me to embody the values I wish to instill in our child.”

   When tempted to react to your co-parent out of frustration or anger, shift the mindset to ask yourself, “What values do I want my child to see me embody right now?” Whether it’s patience, kindness, or composure, this approach helps you stay aligned with your long-term goals.

4. “This is an opportunity to pivot quickly to protect my peace and model self-control.”

   If trusting your co-parent’s intentions feels unrealistic, shift your mindset to focus on your own ability to make a swift, decisive pivot. The goal is not to change your co-parent but to remain in control of your reactions for your child’s benefit. By doing so, you maintain peace and model self-control, which benefits your child in the long term.

   *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

   Exploring Mindset and Paradigm Shifts in Co-parenting

   Invite parents to take a moment to reflect on their current mindset and the historical patterns or paradigms that may influence their co-parenting interactions. Use the following questions to guide their reflection:

   How could a shift in your mindset help you navigate co-parenting challenges more effectively?

   What specific mindset shift could you adopt to reduce reactivity in your interactions with your co-parent?

   Consider a potential paradigm shift: How could re-framing your approach to co-parenting create a more collaborative and positive dynamic?

   How might this new mindset or paradigm positively impact your child and improve your relationship with your co- parent?

   Encourage parents to identify one mindset or paradigm shift they are willing to try, focusing on the benefits it could bring to their co-parenting experience and their child’s well-being.

   *KEY TAKEAWAY*

   Mindset shifts and changing our historical paradigms are the foundation of behavioral change. By focusing on changing our mindset and historical paradigms, we create space for healthier behaviors to follow naturally, leading to more positive outcomes in our co-parenting relationships and for our children’s well-being.

   **UNDERSTANDING ANGER | DIGGING DEEPER WITH COGNITIVE RE-FRAMES** 

   *FACILITATOR’S EXPLANATION*

   Anger is often a surface-level emotion that hides deeper feelings like fear, hurt, or disappointment. Sometimes, our anger is displaced from past experiences, and we project it onto the present situation.

   *REFLECTION ACTIVITY*

   Complete the Roots of Anger Worksheet. Encourage parents to explore the underlying emotions behind their anger and discuss how cognitive re-framing can help them manage these emotions more effectively.

   Facilitator challenges participants with going beyond feelings like anger, irritation and frustration when naming their emotions to truly garner a better understanding of their needs.
